questions.stem: A neuropsychologist evaluates a 58-year-old patient referred for cognitive complaints following a motor vehicle accident. On the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), the patient completes only 2 categories and produces 48 perseverative errors. When informed that a sort is incorrect, the patient continues sorting by the same previously correct principle. This pattern of performance is MOST associated with dysfunction in which brain region?

options.text: Left temporal lobe
Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Right parietal lobe
Occipital cortex

questions.explanation: Elevated perseverative errors on the WCST are the hallmark indicator of frontal lobe dysfunction, specifically the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Perseverative errors reflect an inability to shift cognitive set when environmental demands change (cognitive inflexibility). The patient continues applying a previously reinforced sorting rule despite negative feedback, demonstrating impaired set-shifting ability. This is one of the most commonly tested neuropsychological associations on the EPPP. The temporal lobe is more associated with memory and language; the parietal lobe with visuospatial processing; and the occipital lobe with visual processing.

questions.stem: A geriatric neuropsychologist needs to screen a 72-year-old patient with 8 years of education for mild cognitive impairment (MCI). The patient's MMSE score is 26/30, placing them in the 'normal' range. However, the clinician suspects early cognitive decline. Which instrument would be MORE appropriate for detecting MCI in this patient?

options.text: Bender-Gestalt II
Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)
Halstead-Reitan Category Test
Trail Making Test Part A

questions.explanation: The MoCA was specifically designed to address the MMSE's well-known limitation of poor sensitivity for detecting mild cognitive impairment. The MMSE has sensitivity of approximately 18% for MCI, while the MoCA has approximately 90% sensitivity. This discrepancy is because the MoCA includes executive function tasks (Trail Making B adaptation, clock drawing, abstraction) that the MMSE lacks, and the MoCA has a higher ceiling, reducing the education bias that inflates MMSE scores in more educated individuals. The MoCA also adds 1 point for individuals with 12 or fewer years of education. A score of 26/30 on the MMSE does not rule out MCI, making the MoCA the superior screening choice.

questions.stem: A patient with a documented left frontal lobe lesion is assessed with verbal fluency tasks. Based on the typical neurocognitive profile for this lesion location, which pattern of performance is MOST expected?

options.text: Impaired phonemic (letter) fluency with relatively preserved semantic (category) fluency
Impaired semantic (category) fluency with relatively preserved phonemic (letter) fluency
Equally impaired performance on both phonemic and semantic fluency tasks
Normal performance on both fluency tasks because fluency is a right hemisphere function

questions.explanation: Phonemic (letter) fluency (e.g., FAS/CFL test -- generating words beginning with F, A, S) is primarily associated with left frontal lobe functioning and is more impaired in frontal lobe lesions and subcortical dementias. Semantic (category) fluency (e.g., generating animal names) is more strongly associated with temporal lobe functioning and semantic memory stores. The pattern of letter fluency worse than category fluency suggests frontal or subcortical dysfunction. The reverse pattern (category worse than letter) is the classic Alzheimer's disease pattern, reflecting temporal lobe pathology. This fluency dissociation is a frequently tested neuropsychological concept.

questions.stem: On the Halstead-Reitan Battery, a patient's Finger Tapping Test reveals that the left hand taps significantly faster than the right hand (left = 52, right = 38). The patient is right-handed. This finding MOST suggests dysfunction in which brain region?

options.text: Right hemisphere
Left hemisphere
Cerebellum
Bilateral frontal lobes

questions.explanation: Each hemisphere primarily controls motor function on the contralateral (opposite) side of the body. In right-handed individuals, the dominant (right) hand normally taps approximately 10% faster than the non-dominant (left) hand. When this pattern is reversed -- with the non-dominant left hand outperforming the dominant right hand -- it suggests dysfunction in the left hemisphere, which controls right-hand motor function. The reversal of the expected dominant-hand advantage, combined with the magnitude of the discrepancy (14 taps), provides strong evidence for left hemisphere pathology. This lateralization principle is a cornerstone of neuropsychological interpretation.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist uses the Boston Process Approach (Kaplan) to evaluate a patient's performance on Block Design. Rather than focusing solely on the patient's total score, the neuropsychologist carefully examines HOW the patient constructs each design. What is the PRIMARY advantage of this approach over standard quantitative scoring?

options.text: It produces higher interrater reliability than standardized scoring
It reveals qualitative aspects of performance such as error types, strategies, and lateralized deficits that quantitative scores alone may miss
It eliminates the need for normative comparison by focusing on individual performance patterns
It allows the clinician to administer fewer tests, saving time in the evaluation

questions.explanation: Edith Kaplan's process approach emphasizes qualitative analysis of HOW a patient arrives at a response, not just WHETHER the response is correct. On Block Design, for example, the process approach examines whether the patient produces broken configurations (suggesting parietal dysfunction), works from left to right vs. right to left (lateralization clues), makes specific error types, and uses particular strategies. Two patients can achieve the same total score through very different cognitive processes, and the process approach reveals these clinically meaningful differences. It does not replace quantitative scoring but supplements it, and it does not necessarily improve interrater reliability or reduce testing time.

questions.stem: Select ALL components that are part of the Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Battery (HRNB).

options.text: Category Test
Tactual Performance Test (TPT)
Finger Oscillation (Finger Tapping) Test
Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)
Trail Making Test (Parts A and B)
Boston Naming Test (BNT)

questions.explanation: The Halstead-Reitan Battery includes the Category Test (abstract concept formation), Tactual Performance Test (tactile form recognition, spatial memory), Finger Oscillation/Finger Tapping Test (motor speed), Speech Sounds Perception Test, Seashore Rhythm Test, and the Trail Making Test (Parts A and B). The WCST is a separate standalone executive function measure, not part of the HRNB, though it is frequently administered alongside it. The Boston Naming Test is a standalone confrontation naming test that is also administered separately. These distinctions about battery membership are frequently tested on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Select ALL characteristics that differentiate the Luria-Nebraska Neuropsychological Battery (LNNB) from the Halstead-Reitan Battery (HRNB).

options.text: The LNNB is shorter to administer (2-3 hours vs. 6-8 hours for HRNB)
The LNNB is based on A. R. Luria's qualitative neuropsychological assessment theory
The LNNB includes 11 clinical scales and 3 additional summary scales (Pathognomonic, Left, Right)
The LNNB has more extensive normative data and validation research than the HRNB
The LNNB uses a flexible battery approach while the HRNB uses a fixed battery approach

questions.explanation: Three key differences between the LNNB and HRNB: (1) The LNNB is significantly shorter (2-3 hours vs. 6-8 hours). (2) The LNNB was developed to standardize Luria's qualitative assessment approach into a quantitative format. (3) The LNNB includes 11 clinical scales (Motor, Rhythm, Tactile, Visual, Receptive Speech, Expressive Speech, Writing, Reading, Arithmetic, Memory, Intellectual Processes) plus Pathognomonic, Left Hemisphere, and Right Hemisphere scales. The HRNB actually has MORE extensive validation research. Both batteries use a fixed approach (same tests for all patients), not flexible.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that are TRUE about the Rey-Osterrieth Complex Figure Test (ROCF).

options.text: The test involves copying a complex geometric figure, followed by immediate and delayed recall drawings
Poor organizational strategy during the copy phase (piecemeal approach) is associated with executive dysfunction and predicts poor recall
Intact copy with impaired recall suggests a visual memory deficit rather than a constructional problem
The figure is divided into 18 scorable elements, each scored 0-2 for accuracy and placement, with a maximum score of 36
The ROCF is primarily used to assess verbal memory and language functioning

questions.explanation: The ROCF assesses visuospatial construction, planning/organization, and visual memory. It involves copying a complex figure, then reproducing it from memory (immediate and delayed). The figure has 18 elements scored 0-2 (max 36). Organizational strategy during copy reveals executive functioning: a configurational approach (starting with the global structure) predicts better recall, while a piecemeal approach (focusing on details) indicates executive dysfunction and predicts poor recall. Intact copy with poor recall indicates visual memory deficit (right temporal/hippocampal). The ROCF assesses visuospatial, not verbal, functions.

questions.stem: Select ALL of the three core executive functions identified by Miyake et al. (2000).

options.text: Shifting (cognitive flexibility, set-shifting)
Updating (monitoring and manipulating working memory contents)
Inhibition (suppressing prepotent responses)
Consolidation (transferring information from short-term to long-term memory)
Retrieval (accessing stored information from long-term memory)

questions.explanation: Miyake et al. (2000) conducted an influential study identifying three core executive functions that are moderately correlated but dissociable: (1) Shifting -- cognitive flexibility and set-shifting, measured by WCST and Trail Making B. (2) Updating -- monitoring and manipulating working memory contents, measured by N-back tasks and digit span backward. (3) Inhibition -- suppressing prepotent or dominant responses, measured by Stroop test and Go/No-Go tasks. These three components contribute independently to more complex executive tasks like planning and problem-solving. Consolidation and retrieval are memory processes, not executive functions in Miyake's framework.

questions.stem: Select ALL neuropsychological tests or measures that are commonly used to assess EXECUTIVE FUNCTION.

options.text: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)
Trail Making Test Part B
Stroop Color-Word Test (interference condition)
Boston Naming Test (BNT)
Tower of London / Tower of Hanoi
Delis-Kaplan Executive Function System (D-KEFS)

questions.explanation: Executive function measures include: WCST (cognitive flexibility/set-shifting via perseverative errors), Trail Making B (set-shifting between numbers and letters), Stroop interference condition (inhibitory control), Tower of London/Hanoi (planning and problem-solving), and D-KEFS (comprehensive battery of 9 executive function tests including Trail Making, Color-Word Interference, and Sorting Test). The Boston Naming Test measures confrontation naming ability, which is a language function, not executive function. The BNT is sensitive to anomia in aphasia and neurodegenerative disease but does not assess executive processes.

questions.stem: Match each neuropsychological test to the PRIMARY cognitive function it assesses.
questions.explanation: WCST primarily measures cognitive flexibility and set-shifting (perseverative errors = frontal lobe dysfunction). BNT measures confrontation naming ability (anomia = language/temporal lobe dysfunction). Stroop interference condition measures inhibitory control (suppressing automatic reading response). ROCF copy phase measures visuospatial construction and organizational strategy. CPT measures sustained attention and vigilance (omission errors = inattention, commission errors = impulsivity). Each test targets a specific cognitive domain, and understanding these associations is essential for neuropsychological interpretation.

questions.stem: Match each cognitive screening instrument feature to the correct instrument (MMSE or MoCA).

rows.text: Cutoff score of less than 24 for impairment
Cutoff score of less than 26 for impairment
Includes Trail Making B adaptation and clock drawing

questions.explanation: The MMSE uses a cutoff of less than 24 for cognitive impairment and has poor sensitivity for MCI (~18%) because it lacks executive function tasks and has a ceiling effect in educated individuals. The MoCA uses a cutoff of less than 26, includes executive function tasks (Trail Making B adaptation, clock drawing, abstraction), and has MCI sensitivity of approximately 90%. Both score out of 30 and take about 10 minutes to administer. The MoCA was specifically developed to address the MMSE's limitations in detecting early cognitive decline.

questions.stem: For each Halstead-Reitan interpretive method, select ALL characteristics that apply.

columns.text: Examines the profile of strengths and weaknesses across tests
Compares performance between the two sides of the body
Identifies specific indicators strongly associated with brain dysfunction
Provides information about lateralization of dysfunction

questions.explanation: The Halstead-Reitan Battery uses four interpretive methods: (1) Level of performance -- comparing individual scores to normative cutoffs to determine impairment. (2) Pattern of performance -- examining the profile of strengths and weaknesses across multiple tests to identify characteristic cognitive patterns. (3) Right-left comparisons -- comparing performance between left and right sides of the body (e.g., finger tapping, grip strength) to identify lateralized dysfunction (contralateral hemisphere pathology). (4) Pathognomonic signs -- identifying specific indicators (e.g., dysnomia, sensory suppression) that are strongly and specifically associated with brain dysfunction. All four methods contribute to comprehensive neuropsychological interpretation.

questions.stem: For each type of verbal fluency impairment pattern, select ALL associated conditions.

rows.text: Letter (phonemic) fluency worse than category (semantic) fluency
Category (semantic) fluency worse than letter (phonemic) fluency

questions.explanation: The pattern of verbal fluency impairment provides important diagnostic information. Letter (phonemic) fluency worse than category (semantic) fluency is associated with frontal lobe damage and subcortical dementias (Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease) because phonemic fluency requires frontal-mediated strategic search processes. Category (semantic) fluency worse than letter (phonemic) fluency is the classic Alzheimer's disease pattern and is associated with temporal lobe dysfunction because semantic fluency depends on intact semantic memory stores in the temporal lobes. This dissociation pattern is one of the most frequently tested neuropsychological concepts on the EPPP.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about the Trail Making Test and its clinical interpretation.
The Trail Making Test consists of two parts. Part A requires connecting [BLANK1] in sequential order and primarily measures [BLANK2]. Part B requires alternating between [BLANK3] and additionally measures [BLANK4]. A large discrepancy between Parts A and B (with B disproportionately slow) suggests [BLANK5] beyond simple processing speed deficits. The Trail Making Test is part of the [BLANK6] neuropsychological battery.
questions.explanation: Trail Making Part A (connect numbers 1-25) measures visual scanning and psychomotor speed. Part B (alternate 1-A-2-B-3-C...) additionally measures cognitive flexibility and set-shifting (executive function). A disproportionate A-B discrepancy (B much slower than A) indicates executive dysfunction beyond simple motor slowing. If both A and B are proportionally slow, the deficit is more likely processing speed or motor impairment. The Trail Making Test is included in the Halstead-Reitan Battery. The D-KEFS includes an expanded version with 5 conditions to isolate specific component processes.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about the Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index.
The Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index is calculated by dividing the [BLANK1] by the total number of tests in the battery. The index ranges from [BLANK2] to [BLANK3]. A cutoff of [BLANK4] or above is commonly used to suggest the presence of brain dysfunction. The most sensitive single test in the Halstead-Reitan Battery for detecting brain damage is the [BLANK5].

options: number of tests falling in the impaired range
total number of errors across all tests
blank1.correct: number of tests falling in the impaired range

questions.explanation: The Impairment Index is the proportion of tests falling in the impaired range out of the total tests in the battery. It ranges from 0.0 (no impairment) to 1.0 (all tests impaired). A score of 0.4 or above suggests brain dysfunction. The Category Test, which measures abstract concept formation and the ability to learn from feedback, is considered the most sensitive single test in the HRNB for detecting brain damage. However, the Impairment Index alone is insufficient for localization or specific diagnosis and must be interpreted alongside pattern analysis and lateralization indicators.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist evaluates a 65-year-old patient with progressive memory complaints. Testing reveals: MMSE = 27/30, MoCA = 21/30, WMS-IV delayed recall significantly impaired, BNT = 48/60 (impaired), semantic fluency (animals) = 8 (impaired), phonemic fluency (FAS) = 32 (average), WCST = normal categories and perseverative errors, ROCF copy = 34/36 (intact), ROCF delayed recall = 12/36 (impaired).
questions.explanation: This profile is classic early Alzheimer's disease: impaired delayed memory (hippocampal), impaired naming/anomia (temporal lobe), category fluency worse than letter fluency (temporal > frontal involvement), preserved executive function (frontal lobes relatively spared early), and intact visuospatial construction with impaired visual memory (temporal memory deficit, not parietal constructional deficit). The MoCA detected impairment (21/30) that the MMSE missed (27/30), demonstrating its superior sensitivity. All four right-side options correctly describe key diagnostic indicators in this case.

leftColumn.label: This Pattern Is MOST Consistent With

options.text: Early Alzheimer's disease (temporal lobe pattern)
Frontotemporal dementia (frontal lobe pattern)
Parkinson's disease dementia (subcortical pattern)
Category fluency worse than letter fluency is the classic Alzheimer's dissociation reflecting temporal lobe pathology
MoCA detected impairment that the MMSE missed, confirming MoCA's superior MCI sensitivity
Intact ROCF copy with impaired recall indicates a memory storage deficit, not a constructional problem
Normal WCST suggests that frontal/executive functions are relatively preserved at this stage
The impaired BNT score is expected because confrontation naming is commonly impaired in Alzheimer's disease

questions.centerStatement: Impaired delayed memory, impaired naming, impaired semantic fluency with preserved phonemic fluency, preserved executive function, intact visuospatial construction

questions.stem: A forensic neuropsychologist evaluates a 35-year-old plaintiff in a personal injury case claiming severe cognitive impairment following a mild TBI. The TOMM Trial 2 score is 38/50 (below the 45/50 cutoff). The WAIS-IV Reliable Digit Span is 5 (below the cutoff of 7). However, the plaintiff was observed speaking fluently and navigating the hospital complex without difficulty.
questions.explanation: This case demonstrates classic indicators of malingered cognitive dysfunction: failed standalone PVT (TOMM 38/50; cutoff 45/50), failed embedded validity indicator (RDS 5; cutoff 7), and discrepancy between test performance and observed functioning. Even severely impaired patients (including those with documented dementia) typically score above chance on the TOMM, making scores below 45/50 highly suspicious. The convergence of two independent validity measures plus behavioral observation provides strong evidence for insufficient effort. The Slick et al. (1999) criteria provide a framework for classifying this as Probable malingered neurocognitive dysfunction. Cognitive test results should NOT be interpreted at face value when validity measures are failed.

options.text: Insufficient effort / probable malingering of cognitive dysfunction
Genuine severe cognitive impairment consistent with the reported TBI
Convergent evidence from a standalone PVT and an embedded validity indicator strengthens the conclusion
Below-chance TOMM performance is especially diagnostic because genuinely impaired patients typically score above chance
Interpret the cognitive test results at face value despite failed validity measures
Note the discrepancy between test performance and observed real-world behavior in the report
Consider administering additional validity measures (e.g., SIRS-2 if psychiatric symptoms also claimed)
Apply the Slick, Sherman, and Iverson criteria for classifying malingered neurocognitive dysfunction

questions.centerStatement: Below-cutoff scores on TOMM (38/50) and Reliable Digit Span (5), with discrepancy between test performance and observed real-world functioning

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that CORRECTLY describe the fixed battery vs. flexible battery approaches in neuropsychological assessment.
questions.passage: (1) The fixed battery approach administers a standard set of tests to every patient regardless of the referral question. (2) The Halstead-Reitan Battery is the prototypical fixed battery approach. (3) The flexible battery approach selects tests based on the specific referral question, patient history, and emerging findings during evaluation. (4) The fixed battery approach requires less clinician expertise because the same tests are always administered. (5) The flexible approach is more time-efficient because it avoids administering tests irrelevant to the referral question. (6) Contemporary neuropsychological practice typically uses a purely fixed approach with no modifications for individual patients. (7) The Boston Process Approach (Kaplan) emphasizes qualitative analysis of how the patient approaches tasks, not just quantitative scores.
correctHighlights: (1) The fixed battery approach administers a standard set of tests to every patient regardless of the referral question.
(2) The Halstead-Reitan Battery is the prototypical fixed battery approach.
(3) The flexible battery approach selects tests based on the specific referral question, patient history, and emerging findings during evaluation.
(5) The flexible approach is more time-efficient because it avoids administering tests irrelevant to the referral question.
(7) The Boston Process Approach (Kaplan) emphasizes qualitative analysis of how the patient approaches tasks, not just quantitative scores.
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 3, 5, and 7 are correct. Statement 4 is incorrect: while the fixed battery always uses the same tests, interpreting the results still requires substantial clinical expertise. Statement 6 is incorrect: contemporary practice typically BLENDS approaches, using a core set of standardized measures supplemented by hypothesis-driven additional tests with qualitative process observations. A purely fixed approach without any individualization does not reflect current best practices. The referral question, patient demographics, and available time guide the specific battery composition.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are CORRECT about the Bender Visual Motor Gestalt Test (Bender-Gestalt).
questions.passage: (1) The Bender-Gestalt was originally developed by Lauretta Bender based on Gestalt psychology principles. (2) The test requires the examinee to copy geometric designs, assessing visual-motor integration. (3) The Koppitz Developmental Scoring System is used primarily with children ages 5-11 and scores errors across categories of distortion, rotation, integration, and perseveration. (4) The Bender-Gestalt is a comprehensive diagnostic tool that can reliably differentiate between specific brain lesion locations. (5) The Bender-Gestalt II added a recall phase and expanded normative data for ages 4-85+. (6) The Lacks Scoring System is designed for adults and identifies 12 essential discriminators of organic brain impairment.
correctHighlights: (1) The Bender-Gestalt was originally developed by Lauretta Bender based on Gestalt psychology principles.
(2) The test requires the examinee to copy geometric designs, assessing visual-motor integration.
(3) The Koppitz Developmental Scoring System is used primarily with children ages 5-11 and scores errors across categories of distortion, rotation, integration, and perseveration.
(5) The Bender-Gestalt II added a recall phase and expanded normative data for ages 4-85+.
(6) The Lacks Scoring System is designed for adults and identifies 12 essential discriminators of organic brain impairment.
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct. Statement 4 is incorrect: the Bender-Gestalt is a SCREENING instrument, not a comprehensive diagnostic tool. It cannot reliably differentiate specific brain lesion locations. Errors such as rotation, fragmentation, perseveration, and collision may suggest neurological impairment but require follow-up with comprehensive neuropsychological testing. The Bender-Gestalt's sensitivity and specificity for detecting brain dysfunction are limited, making it appropriate for screening purposes only.

questions.stem: Arrange the following neuropsychological tests from SHORTEST to LONGEST typical administration time.

items.text: MMSE (~10 minutes)
Halstead-Reitan Battery (~6-8 hours)
Luria-Nebraska Battery (~2-3 hours)
Bender-Gestalt copy phase (~5-10 minutes)
D-KEFS full battery (~90 minutes)

questions.explanation: From shortest to longest: Bender-Gestalt copy phase (5-10 minutes) is the briefest screening tool. MMSE (approximately 10 minutes) is a brief cognitive screening. D-KEFS full battery (approximately 90 minutes) is a focused executive function assessment. Luria-Nebraska Battery (2-3 hours) is a comprehensive neuropsychological battery that is shorter than the HRNB. Halstead-Reitan Battery (6-8 hours) is the most time-intensive comprehensive battery. Understanding administration times is important for practical clinical decision-making about which battery to use given available time and the referral question.

questions.stem: Arrange the following indicators of neuropsychological impairment from MOST SPECIFIC (strongest evidence of brain dysfunction) to LEAST SPECIFIC.

items.text: Below-chance performance on a forced-choice validity test (e.g., TOMM < 25/50)
Pathognomonic signs (e.g., dysnomia, sensory extinction)
Overall Impairment Index above 0.4 on the Halstead-Reitan
Double dissociation pattern across two tasks and two patients
Single subtest score 1 SD below the mean

questions.explanation: From most specific evidence of brain dysfunction to least: (1) Double dissociation is the strongest evidence that two functions are independent and served by different brain regions. (2) Pathognomonic signs (dysnomia, sensory extinction, specific aphasia patterns) are strongly and specifically associated with brain dysfunction. (3) The Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index above 0.4 suggests brain dysfunction but does not localize. (4) A single subtest score 1 SD below the mean is relatively common in normal populations and is the least specific indicator. (5) Below-chance performance on a forced-choice test is actually evidence of malingering rather than brain dysfunction, making it irrelevant to the specificity question about genuine impairment.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist compares Trail Making Test Part A and Part B performance across three patient groups: healthy controls, patients with frontal lobe lesions, and patients with diffuse subcortical white matter disease. Which pattern of results is MOST expected?

options.text: All three groups show proportionally similar A and B times, with the clinical groups simply slower overall
Frontal patients show a disproportionately large B-A discrepancy compared to healthy controls, while subcortical patients show proportionally slowed A and B times
Subcortical patients show the largest B-A discrepancy because white matter disease primarily affects executive function
Healthy controls show the largest B-A discrepancy because their faster Part A times make the ratio larger

questions.explanation: The B-A discrepancy pattern is diagnostically important. Frontal lobe patients typically show a disproportionately large B-A discrepancy because Part B's set-shifting demand (alternating numbers-letters) requires executive function mediated by the frontal lobes, while Part A's simple sequencing is relatively spared. Subcortical white matter disease typically produces proportional slowing on both parts (generalized processing speed deficit) without the disproportionate B-A discrepancy, because the slowing reflects degraded white matter connectivity rather than frontal executive dysfunction per se. This interpretive distinction between proportional slowing and disproportionate B-A discrepancy is clinically important.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist tracks cognitive screening scores (MoCA) over 3 years for two patients: one with early Alzheimer's disease (AD) and one with normal aging. Which trajectory pattern is MOST expected?

options.text: Both patients show gradual, parallel decline at the same rate
The AD patient shows progressive decline crossing below the clinical cutoff, while the normal aging patient remains stable above the cutoff
Both patients remain stable above the cutoff throughout the 3 years
The normal aging patient declines faster than the AD patient due to less cognitive reserve

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease produces progressive cognitive decline that accelerates over time, reflecting the neurodegenerative process affecting hippocampal and temporal lobe structures. MoCA scores in AD patients typically show a trajectory of approximately 2-4 points per year decline, crossing progressively further below the clinical cutoff (26). In contrast, normal cognitive aging produces minimal MoCA score changes (0-1 point per year at most), with scores remaining at or near the normal range. This diverging trajectory pattern highlights the importance of serial cognitive screening for detecting and monitoring neurodegenerative disease, as a single time-point assessment may not differentiate early AD from normal aging.

questions.stem: Categorize each neuropsychological finding according to the brain region whose dysfunction it MOST strongly suggests.

items.text: Perseverative errors on the WCST
Impaired confrontation naming (anomia) on the BNT
Impaired Stroop interference performance
Sensory extinction during bilateral simultaneous stimulation
Impaired semantic (category) fluency with preserved letter fluency
Hemispatial neglect (failure to attend to contralateral space)

questions.explanation: Frontal lobe dysfunction is indicated by: WCST perseverative errors (impaired cognitive flexibility/set-shifting from dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) and impaired Stroop interference (impaired inhibitory control). Temporal lobe dysfunction is indicated by: impaired confrontation naming/anomia on the BNT (language areas in dominant temporal lobe) and impaired semantic fluency with preserved letter fluency (degraded semantic memory stores). Parietal lobe dysfunction is indicated by: sensory extinction during bilateral simultaneous stimulation (contralateral parietal processing) and hemispatial neglect (typically right parietal, causing left-side neglect). These brain-behavior associations are foundational to neuropsychological practice.

questions.stem: Categorize each neuropsychological assessment approach as either FIXED BATTERY or FLEXIBLE/PROCESS APPROACH.

items.text: Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Battery
Luria-Nebraska Neuropsychological Battery
Boston Process Approach (Kaplan)
Hypothesis-testing approach selecting tests based on referral question
Same comprehensive set of tests administered to every patient
Qualitative analysis of HOW a patient approaches tasks, not just scores

questions.explanation: Fixed battery approaches (Halstead-Reitan, Luria-Nebraska) administer the same comprehensive set of tests to every patient regardless of the referral question, providing standardized normative comparison but potentially including irrelevant tests. Flexible/process approaches (Boston Process Approach, hypothesis-testing) select tests based on the referral question and emphasize qualitative analysis of how the patient approaches tasks. The Boston Process Approach specifically emphasizes process over product -- how the patient arrives at answers, not just whether answers are correct. Contemporary practice typically blends both approaches: a core fixed battery supplemented by hypothesis-driven tests with qualitative observation.
